Gaeng Djued Fak Khiau Graduk On.thai: แกงจืดฟักเขียวกระดูกอ่อน
Gaeng Djued Fak Khiau Graduk On.title_en: Thai Winter Melon Soup with Baby Pork Ribs
Gaeng Djued Fak Khiau Graduk On.transcript_de: Gaeng Djued Fak Khiau Graduk On

Gaeng Djued Wun Sen.thai: แกงจืดวุ้นเส้น

Khao Pad Horapa.thai: ข้าวผัดโหระพา

Moo Tod Gratiem.thai: หมูทอดกระเทียม

Moo Tod Prik Gaeng.title_de: Deep Fried Pork Belly with Basil Leaves
Moo Tod Prik Gaeng.title_en: Deep Fried Pork Belly with Basil Leaves

Pad Dok Kachorn Gung.thai: ผัดดอกขจรกุ้ง

Pad Ga Prau Hoi Shell.thai: ผัดกะเพราหอยลาย

Pad Hed Nam Prik Gapi.thai: ผัดเห็ดน้ำพริกกะปิ

Pad Nor Mai Farang Tao Hu.thai: ผัดหน่อไม้ฝรั่งเต้าหู้
Pad Nor Mai Farang Tao Hu.transcript_de: Pad Nor Mai Farang Tao Hu

Sup Nuea Islam.thai: ซุปเนื้ออิสลาม

Tao Hu Khai.thai: เต้าหู้ไข่

Tao Hu Khai Thod Sai Mhu Sap.thai: เต้าหู้ไข่ทอดใส่หมูสับ
Tao Hu Khai Thod Sai Mhu Sap.title_en: Crispy Egg Tofu Topped With Minced Pork
Tao Hu Khai Thod Sai Mhu Sap.transcript_de: Tao Hu Khai Thod Sai Mhu Sap

Tom Khlong.thai: ไก่ต้มขมิ้น

Tom Takrai Hoi.thai: ต้มตะไคร้หอย

Yam Takrai Gung Sod.thai: ยำตะไคร้กุ้งสด

Yam Takrai Mhu.thai: ยำตะไคร้หมู

aep-mu.notes: A Northern Thai " soufflé " of egg, minced pork, herbs, and curry paste that is slowly grilled inside a banana leaf wrapper over a charcoal fire.

aep-ong-o.notes: Roughly chopped pig's brain mixed with egg and curry paste are grilled over a low fire, wrapped inside banana leaves.
aep-ong-o.thai: แอ็บอ่องออ

aep-pla-noi.notes: Freshwater small fry and brine shrimp are mixed with curry paste and then grilled over a low fire wrapped inside banana leaves.
aep-pla-noi.thai: แอ็บปลาน้อย

bai-po.notes: Eaten blanched as a dish with khao tom kui (plain rice congee ), the taste is similar to that of spinach or samphire .

bami-haeng-pet.notes: Egg noodles served "dry" with slices of braised duck, and often, as shown on the image, together with "blood tofu". The broth is served on the side. It is originally a Chinese dish.
bami-haeng-pet.thai: บะหมี่แห้งเป็ด

bami-mu-daeng.notes: Originally a Chinese dish, it is now common in Thailand. Often served with chili peppers in vinegar, and dried chili flakes. The version shown in the photo also contains kiao kung ( Thai : เกี๊ยวกุ้ง ; prawn wontons ).
bami-mu-daeng.thai: บะหมี่หมูแดง
bami-mu-daeng.title_de: Egg noodle soup with red roast pork
bami-mu-daeng.title_en: Egg noodle soup with red roast pork

cha-dam-yen.notes: It is made from strongly brewed black tea ("red tea" in East Asia). The tea is sweetened with sugar and served with ice.

cha-manao.notes: It is made from strongly brewed black tea ("red tea" in East Asia). The tea is sweetened with sugar flavored with sugar and lime and served hot or with ice. Mint may also be added.

cha-ron.notes: It is made from strongly brewed black tea ("red tea" in East Asia). The tea is sweetened with sugar and condensed milk and served hot.

cha-yen.notes: It is made from strongly brewed black tea ("red tea" in East Asia). Additional ingredients may include orange blossom water, star anise, crushed tamarind seed and sometimes other spices. The tea is sweetened with sugar and condensed milk and served chilled.

chaokuai.notes: Grass jelly is made from a herb from the mint family. It is often served with only shaved ice and brown sugar.

chim-chum.notes: A Thai style hot pot served in an earthenware pot where the ingredients (meats, vegetables, mushrooms, noodles) are cooked in a clear herb broth of lemongrass, galangal, and kaffir lime leaves. Additionally, the broth can contain other herbs such as kaphrao ( Thai holy basil ), spices such as chilis, or in addition be partially meat based, using pork ribs for instance as one of the base ingredients. It is served with one or more nam chim (dipping sauces).

chin-hum.notes: It is a slowly stewed meat curry from northern Thailand. This particular version is made with beef.

chin-som-mok.notes: Chin som is the northern Thai version of the pickled pork sausage called naem . In chin som mok (lit. "covered chin som ") the pickled pork is grilled inside a banana leaf before serving.
chin-som-mok.thai: จิ๊นส้มหมก

chingrit-thot.notes: Deep-fried crickets , either Gryllus bimaculatus or, as shown in the image, Acheta domesticus . This dish is often eaten as a snack to go with drinks.
chingrit-thot.thai: จิ้งหรีดทอด

chok.notes: Of Chinese origin, it is a rice congee with minced chicken or pork. Mixing an egg in with the congee is optional.

chuchi-pla-kaphong.notes: A semi-dry red curry with fried Snapper .
chuchi-pla-kaphong.thai: ฉู่ฉี่ปลากะพง

chuchi-pla-thu-sot.notes: A semi-dry curry made with fresh (i.e. unsteamed and unsalted) pla thu ( Rastrelliger brachysoma ). The version in the image was made at a southern Thai restaurant.
chuchi-pla-thu-sot.thai: ฉู่ฉี่ปลาทูสด

dara-thong.notes: Dara thong or thong ek krachang (ทองเอกกระจัง) is a golden dough ball made from wheat flour, egg yolks, coconut milk, and sugar, topped with a little piece of gold leaf, and decorated with sugar-coated, dry-fried watermelon seeds. Nowadays, it is often wrongly referred to as cha mongkut (จ่ามงกุฎ), which is the name of another Thai traditional sweet.

foi-thong.notes: The name translates to "golden threads", it is a sweet snack or dessert of strings of egg yolk shortly boiled in sugar syrup. This, and other egg-based sweets such as sangkhaya , were introduced to the royal court of Ayutthaya by Maria Guyomar de Pinha in the 17th century CE.

ho-mok-maphrao-on.notes: A Thai steamed curry with mixed seafood and the soft meat of a young coconut, here served inside a coconut.
ho-mok-maphrao-on.thai: ห่อหมกมะพร้าวอ่อน

ho-mok-pla.notes: A Thai steamed curry with fish, spices, coconut milk, and egg, steam-cooked in a banana leaf cup and topped with thick coconut cream before serving.

kaeng-cha-om.notes: A northern Thai curry with cha-om (the young leaves of the Acacia pennata ) and dried fish. This particular version also contained a mix of different types of mushroom.

kaeng-dok-salae.notes: A northern Thai curry that is made from the unopened flower buds of the shrub Broussonetia kurzii (J. D. Hooker) Corner. These flower buds are available in northern Thailand only from mid-February until late March.
kaeng-dok-salae.thai: แกงดอกสะแล

kaeng-fak-sai-kai.notes: A northern Thai curry made with winter melon and chicken. It is also known under the name kaeng fak khio .
kaeng-fak-sai-kai.thai: แกงฟักใส่ไก่

kaeng-hangle.notes: A Burmese influenced curry of stewed meat (usually pork), peanuts, dried chili peppers and tamarind juice but without coconut milk. Thin strips of fresh ginger are added in before serving.

kaeng-het.notes: A northern Thai curry made with pork and a variety of mushrooms.

kaeng-ho.notes: A Northern Thai dish where one or more types of curry are refried with glass noodles and other ingredients such as kaffir lime leaves, lemongrass, and bamboo shoots. At least one of the curries used in this recipe should be the Northern Thai pork curry called kaeng hangle .

kaeng-kari.notes: It is a Thai-Muslim dish which is mostly known in the West as "Thai yellow curry". It is of Indian origin and is often made with chicken and potatoes. It can also be made with other meats or seafood.

kaeng-khae.notes: A spicy curry of herbs, vegetables, cha-om leaves (a kind of acacia tree), and meat (chicken, water buffalo, pork, or frog meat). It does not contain any coconut milk.

kaeng-khanun.notes: A northern Thai curry made with boiled whole jackfruit , pork, tomatoes, and chopped chakhan ( Piper interruptum ; "pepper vine").

kaeng-khiao-wan.notes: A coconut curry made with fresh green chili peppers and flavored with Thai basil, usually with chicken ( kaeng khiao wan kai ) or fish balls .
kaeng-khiao-wan.thai: แกงเขียวหวาน

kaeng-khilek.notes: This creamy curry has as its main ingredient the leaves and flower buds of the Senna siamea tree ( khilek in Thai).
kaeng-khilek.thai: แกงขี้เหล็ก

kaeng-khua.notes: A type of Thai curry which uses a larger amount of turmeric in the paste than is usually the norm. A popular preparation is with prawns and pineapple. This particular version is called kaeng khua het fang ( Thai : แกงคั่วเห็ดฟาง ): with straw mushrooms .

kaeng-khua-mu-bai-chamuang.notes: A thick central Thai curry with pork and the leaves of chamuang or Garcinia cowa , a tree related to the mangosteen .
kaeng-khua-mu-bai-chamuang.thai: แกงคั่วหมูใบชะมวง

kaeng-kradang.notes: A pork curry aspic (jelly) from northern Thailand which is eaten cold.
kaeng-kradang.thai: แกงกระด้าง

kaeng-lueang.notes: A sour spicy curry that does not contain coconut milk and is yellow in color due to the use of turmeric , often with fish and vegetables, such as bamboo shoots as in the version in the photo. In southern Thailand it is called kaeng som but due to it being different from the central Thai kaeng som , it is called kaeng lueang ("yellow curry") elsewhere. It should not be confused with what is known as " yellow curry " outside of Thailand.

kaeng-matsaman.notes: A rich, thick curry containing coconut milk, usually of stewed beef or, as in the image, chicken. This curry contains roasted dried spices that are rarely found in other Thai curries. The name kaeng matsaman means "Muslim curry", with the spices believed to have been brought to Thailand by Muslim traders in the 17th century. Massaman curry is usually served with rice or roti.
kaeng-matsaman.thai: แกงมัสมั่น

kaeng-om.notes: A spicy Lanna "curry" with meat, and without any coconut milk. The version shown in the photo is with beef.

kaeng-pa.notes: Traditionally made with wild boar , most often pork or chicken is used nowadays. This curry, as most curries from northern Thailand, does not contain coconut milk.

kaeng-phak-bung-sai-pla.notes: A northern Thai curry made with " morning glory " and catfish.
kaeng-phak-bung-sai-pla.thai: แกงผักบุ้งใส่ปลา

kaeng-phak-kat-cho-kraduk-mu.notes: A somewhat spicy soup/curry ( kaeng ) made with cabbage ( phak kat cho , a variety of Brassica rapa chinensis ) and pork ribs ( kraduk mu ). As is usual with Northern Thai "curries", it does not contain any coconut milk.
kaeng-phak-kat-cho-kraduk-mu.thai: แกงผักกาดจอกระดูกหมู
kaeng-phak-kat-cho-kraduk-mu.transcript_de: Kaeng phak kat cho kraduk mu
kaeng-phak-kat-cho-kraduk-mu.transcript_en: Kaeng phak kat cho kraduk mu

kaeng-phak-lueat.notes: A northern Thai curry made with the leaves of the Ficus virens . This version is with pork.
kaeng-phak-lueat.thai: แกงผักเลือด

kaeng-phak-siangda.notes: A northern Thai curry made with the leaves of the vine Gymnema inodorum and dried fish. In this particular version, snakehead fish is used.
kaeng-phak-siangda.thai: แกงผักเซียงดา

kaeng-phak-wan-pa.notes: A Northern Thai curry made with the leaves of the woody plant Melientha suavis Pierre, glass noodles, and dried fish.
kaeng-phak-wan-pa.thai: แกงผักหวานป่า

kaeng-phanaeng.notes: A so-called dry, Malay influenced coconut curry with beef ( phanaeng nuea , Thai : พะแนงเนื้อ ), chicken, pork or seafood such as soft shell crab.

kaeng-phet.notes: A spicy red curry made with dried chili peppers, containing coconut milk. It can be made with different meats, seafood or tofu, in combination with (several types of) eggplant(s), and sometimes other vegetables. Fresh green peppercorns and Thai basil are often added to enhance the flavor.

kaeng-phet-pet-yang.notes: Red curry with roast duck is the quintessential mix of the Thai (red curry) and Chinese (red roast duck) cuisines. This dish often also contains grapes and pineapple.
kaeng-phet-pet-yang.thai: แกงเผ็ดเป็ดย่าง

kaeng-pli.notes: A northern Thai curry made with chopped banana flower and pork.

kaeng-ranchuan.notes: Kaeng ranchuan is a beef curry and fermented shrimp paste chili sauce, similar to tom yam . It was created by chef in royal households from the leftovers and turned in new dish by combining pieces of meat and leftover sauce especially nam phrik kapi . The most popular of all dip is nam phrik kapi , a very delicious sauce of Thailand because this sauce can be eaten with everything. Many Thai chefs reformed kaeng ranchuan to restaurants after it was mentioned by culinary authority ML Nueang Ninrat, in a memoir explaining her life during the reign of King Rama V and VI. The people misunderstand about the origin and preparation of kaeng ranchuan because of famous TV series that do the wrong method of this dish and make people remember that this is the real kaeng ranchuan preparation method. So, the real kaeng ranchuan is in ML Ninrat book "Life in the Palace" she tells how her grandmother, the princess Sabai Ninrat created this dish. At the end of dinner there was leftovers so she asked her assistant to separate the meat from chili and basil. Then, she mixed it into a broth and added leftover of Nam prhrik kapi, so this is called the real kaeng ranchuan .

kaeng-som.notes: A hot and sour Thai curry/soup made with tamarind paste and fish (often pla chon [" Snakehead fish "]). Kaeng som cha-om thot ( Thai : แกงส้มชะอมทอด ) is a version of the dish which features deep-fried cha-om (Acacia leaves) as one of its ingredients.

kaeng-tai-pla.notes: A thick, spicy vegetable curry made with turmeric, a sauce made from fish innards ( tai pla ), and shrimp paste, containing roasted fish, bamboo shoots, and eggplant.

kaeng-thepho.notes: One of the dishes mentioned in the poem of King Rama II on Thai dishes, it is a central Thai curry originally made with the fatty belly part of the Pangasius Larnaudii ( thae pho ; shark catfish) but now more often belly pork is used as is the case with the version shown in the photo. The other main ingredient in this curry is phak bung Chin (Chinese water spinach ).

kaeng-tun.notes: A northern Thai curry made with the stalks of the Colocasia gigantea and catfish. Colocasia gigantea is called tun ( Thai : ตูน ) in the northern Thai language and khun ( Thai : คูน ) in standard Thai.

kaeng-yot-maphrao-on-sai-kai.notes: A northern Thai curry made with " coconut heart " and chicken. The taste of "coconut heart" is similar to bamboo shoots but much sweeter.
kaeng-yot-maphrao-on-sai-kai.thai: แกงยอดมะพร้าวอ่อนใส่ไก่
kaeng-yot-maphrao-on-sai-kai.transcript_de: Kaeng yot maphrao on sai kai
kaeng-yot-maphrao-on-sai-kai.transcript_en: Kaeng yot maphrao on sai kai

kaeng-yuak.notes: A northern Thai curry made with the tender core of the trunk of the banana plant.

kafae-boran.notes: Kafae boran literally translates to "ancient/traditional coffee". It is a strong coffee that is served with sweetened condensed milk , similar in taste to the kopi that is served at kopi tiam (traditional coffee shops) of Malaysia and Singapore. It is usually made with robusta coffee beans, by steeping the grounds inside a brewing "sock".

kai-ho-bai-toei.notes: Pieces of marinated chicken are wrapped in fragrant pandan leaves and then deep fried. [2]
kai-ho-bai-toei.thai: ไก่ห่อใบเตย

kai-phat-khing.notes: A simple dish of fried slices of chicken with sliced ginger, soy sauce, fish sauce, and chili peppers.

kai-phat-met-mamuang-himmaphan.notes: The Thai Chinese version of the Sichuan style fried chicken with cashew nuts known as Kung Pao chicken , stir-fried with whole dried chili peppers.
kai-phat-met-mamuang-himmaphan.thai: ไก่ผัดเม็ดมะม่วงหิมพานต์

kai-rom-khwan.notes: Smoked chicken is often eaten as a snack to go with drinks.

kai-thot.notes: The version of kai thot as shown in the image is made in the Southern Thai manner, having been marinated with khamin ( turmeric ) and served with krueng thae (crispy fried chopped garlic and turmeric) as a topping.

kai-thot-takhrai.notes: Pieces of chicken are deep fried together with finely chopped or shredded lemongrass, and served with a sweet chili sauce.
kai-thot-takhrai.thai: ไก่ทอดตะไคร้

kai-tun-ya-chin.notes: The name literally translates to "chicken stewed with Chinese medicine". It contains medicinal herbs, one of them the dried fruit of the wolfberry , a.k.a. goji berries ( Thai : เก๋ากี้ ; kaoki ). The dish is of Chinese origin.
kai-tun-ya-chin.thai: ไก่ตุ๋นยาจีน

kai-yang.notes: Grilled marinated chicken, usually eaten together with Som tam (papaya salad).

kaolao.notes: A soup of Chinese origin, usually containing offal, often pork liver and intestines, also boiled eggs, and other meats such as crispy pork. Alternatively, at regular noodle soup shops, it can also be as a regular Thai-Chinese noodle soup but then served without any noodles.

kaphrao-hoi-lai.notes: Undulated surf clam stir-fried with holy basil ( Ocimum tenuiflorum )
kaphrao-hoi-lai.thai: กะเพราหอยลาย
kaphrao-hoi-lai.title_de: Stir-fried baby clams with thai holy basil
kaphrao-hoi-lai.title_en: Stir-fried baby clams with thai holy basil

karipap.notes: In Thailand, Karipap is a popular street food snack that is commonly made by using spring roll wrappers. The filling contains chicken, potato, onion and curry powder. These flat and triangle shaped snacks are derived from the Indian samosas .
karipap.thai: กะหรี่ปั๊บ

khaep-mu.notes: Deep fried crispy pork rinds, often eaten with nam phrik num and other northern Thai dips.

khai-chiao-khai-mot-daeng.notes: A Thai-style crispy-fried omelette which includes the eggs of the red ant.
khai-chiao-khai-mot-daeng.thai: ไข่เจียวไข่มดแดง

khai-dao.notes: Literally translated khai dao means "star egg", referring to the star-like shape of the egg after it has been fried. Traditionally the egg is fried in large amounts of hot vegetable oil which produces a crispy outer texture. Khai dao mai suk is a fried egg where the yolk is still runny, the way it is most commonly eaten when served with, for instance, khao phat ("fried rice") or kaphrao mu rat khao ("pork fried with holy basil served with rice"). Fried egg with a (very) hard yolk, khai dao suk (mak) , is needed when the fried egg is used for making yam khai dao : fried egg salad.

khai-luk-khoei.notes: Boiled eggs are (deep-)fried until crispy on the outside, and then served sliced with a tangy sauce made from tamarind juice. The Thai name literally translates as "son-in-law eggs".

khai-phalo.notes: Egg stewed with meat in soy sauce, garlic, ginger and phong phalo ( Thai : ผงพะโล้ ; five-spice powder ). Meats used in khai phalo tend to be pork (belly or trotter) or chicken wings. Other ingredients, such as mushrooms and fried tofu, can also be incorporated. The dish is of Chinese origin. Similar dishes are mu phalo and kha mu phalo (using only pork, and ham hocks), kai phalo (chicken) and pet phalo (duck).

khai-yat-sai.notes: An omelette is fried filled with various ingredients of choice (minced beef or pork, prawns, and vegetables) and then folded over.

khanom-bua-loi.notes: Taro root mixed with flour into balls and served in coconut milk.

khanom-chan.notes: A multi-colored pudding of layers of sticky rice flour and tapioca flour mixed with coconut milk and sugar. Each layer will be differently scented ( pandan , jasmine and more). It is similar to the Indonesian, Malaysian and Singaporean kueh lapis .

khanom-chin-kaeng-khiao-wan-kai.notes: This noodle dish consists of green chicken curry served over khanom chin , fresh Thai rice noodles. It is usually accompanied by a selection of raw vegetables and herbs on the side. The chicken meat used in this particular version is chicken feet .
khanom-chin-kaeng-khiao-wan-kai.thai: ขนมจีนแกงเขียวหวานไก่
khanom-chin-kaeng-khiao-wan-kai.transcript_de: Khanom chin kaeng khiao wan kai
khanom-chin-kaeng-khiao-wan-kai.transcript_en: Khanom chin kaeng khiao wan kai

khanom-chin-nam-ngiao.notes: A speciality of Northern Thailand, it is Thai fermented rice noodles served with pork or chicken blood tofu in a sauce made with pork broth and tomato, crushed fried dry chili peppers, pork blood, dry fermented soy bean, and dried red kapok flowers.
khanom-chin-nam-ngiao.thai: ขนมจีนน้ำเงี้ยว

khanom-chin-sao-nam.notes: Cold rice noodles served as a salad with thick coconut milk, finely chopped pineapple, sliced raw garlic and Thai chili peppers, pounded dried prawns, shredded ginger, lime juice, fish sauce, and sugar.
khanom-chin-sao-nam.thai: ขนมจีนซาวน้ำ

khanom-chip.notes: The Thai version of the Chinese steamed dumplings called siu mai in Cantonese . The color indicates the filling: the green dumplings contain a mix of minced pork and crab meat, the others have a filling of only minced pork.

khanom-farang-kudi-chin.notes: Small muffins. The main ingredients are duck eggs, sugar and wheat flour. No butter, milk or yeast. No preservatives. The little cakes are topped with raisins, gourds dipped in syrup, and persimmon. [6]
khanom-farang-kudi-chin.thai: ขนมฝรั่งกุฎีจีน

khanom-jeen-nam-yaa.notes: Thai rice noodles served with a fish based sauce called nam ya .
khanom-jeen-nam-yaa.thai: ขนมจีนน้ำยา

khanom-krok.notes: Small coconut hotcakes with different fillings. These are made on a special cast-iron pan with indentations. Two-halves are eventually stuck to one another to form the finished miniature pancake. [7]

khanom-kuichai.notes: Originally a dish of the Teochew people called "gu chai gue" (Chinese script: 韭菜馃) in the Teochew language , these are steamed dumplings made from rice powder and a filling of garlic chives . The dipping sauce for this dish is soy sauce which often is spiced with dried chili flakes. This particular version was fried to give it a crispy texture.
khanom-kuichai.thai: ขนมกุยช่าย

khanom-mo-kaeng.notes: A sweet baked pudding containing coconut milk, eggs, palm sugar, and flour, sprinkled with sweet fried onions.
khanom-mo-kaeng.thai: ขนมหม้อแกง

khanom-piak-pun.notes: The unique smoky flavor and the deep black color comes from coconut ash. It is made from a mix of sticky rice flour and tapioca flour , together with coconut milk and sugar.
khanom-piak-pun.thai: ขนมเปียกปูน

khanom-tako.notes: Jasmine scented coconut pudding set in cups of fragrant pandan leaf.

khanom-tako-phueak.notes: Traditional sweets made with coconut milk, rice, flour, sugar, and boiled taro pieces in a banana leaf cone.
khanom-tako-phueak.thai: ขนมตะโก้เผือก

khanom-tan.notes: Palm flavoured miniature cake with shredded coconut on top.

khanom-thuai-talai.notes: Steamed sweet coconut jelly and cream.
khanom-thuai-talai.thai: ขนมถ้วยตะไล

khanom-tokyo.notes: Literally translated it means "Tokyo cake", it is a Thai style crêpe wrapped around a hot dog and sweet chili sauce. The chili sauce can also be served on the side as a dip. Other versions of khanom Tokiao use yam or sweet condensed milk as a filling.
khanom-tokyo.thai: ขนมโตเกียว

khanom-tom.notes: A Southern Thai snack made from sticky rice, coconut milk, sugar, and salt. The mixture is wrapped in a young mangrove fan palm leaf, formed into a triangle shape, and then boiled or steamed until cooked. Eaten during the Chak Phra Festival.

khanom-wun.notes: These are desserts made with an agar gelatin and the colors represent different flavors.

khao-kan-chin.notes: A dish of the Tai Yai ( Shan people ) of Myanmar and northern Thailand, it is rice that is mixed with pork blood and steamed inside a banana leaf. Khao kan chin is served with cucumber, onions and fried, dried chili peppers.
khao-kan-chin.thai: ข้าวกั๊นจิ๊น

khao-kha-mu.notes: Steamed rice is served with sliced pig's trotters , which has been simmered in soy sauce and five spice powder . It is always served with a sweet spicy dipping sauce, fresh bird's eye chili peppers and cloves of garlic on the side. Boiled egg and a clear broth on the side are optional.

khao-khai-chiao.notes: A quick snack or breakfast, it is an omelette with white rice, often eaten with chili sauce and cucumber. The variant shown in the image is khao khai chiao songkhrueang ( Thai : ข้าวไข่เจียวทรงเครื่อง ) where the omelette is topped with a minced pork and vegetable stir-fry.
khao-khai-chiao.thai: ข้าวไข่เจียว

khao-khluk-kapi.notes: Rice is fried with shrimp paste and served with sweet pork, sour mango, fried shrimp, chili peppers, and shallots.
khao-khluk-kapi.thai: ข้าวคลุกกะปิ

khao-man-gai.notes: Rice steamed with garlic served with sliced chicken, chicken broth, and a spicy dipping sauce. This is a Thai version of a dish called Wenchang chicken (文昌雞) from Hainan in southern China.
khao-man-gai.thai: ข้าวมันไก่

khao-mok-gai.notes: The Thai version of a "chicken biryani". The name literally means "rice covered chicken" and this Thai-Muslim dish is made by cooking rice together with the chicken curry.
khao-mok-gai.thai: ข้าวหมกไก่

khao-mok-nuea.notes: The Thai version of a "beef biryani".
khao-mok-nuea.thai: ข้าวหมกเนื้อ

khao-mu-krop.notes: Rice and crispy pork that is often, as here in this image, served with boiled egg and a bowl of broth. The sauce that always comes with khao mu krop is here served separately in the bowl at the top of the image.
khao-mu-krop.thai: ข้าวหมูกรอบ

khao-mu-krop-mu-daeng.notes: Slices of mu krop (crispy pork) and mu daeng ( red roast pork ) served on rice, and often covered with a sticky soy or oyster-sauce based sauce. Very often, a clear soup, boiled egg, cucumber, and spring onion is served on the side. Sliced chili peppers in Chinese black vinegar and dark soy sauce are provided as a condiment for this dish.
khao-mu-krop-mu-daeng.thai: ข้าวหมูกรอบหมูแดง
khao-mu-krop-mu-daeng.title_de: Mixed crispy pork and red roast pork on rice
khao-mu-krop-mu-daeng.title_en: Mixed crispy pork and red roast pork on rice

khao-na-pet.notes: Boiled rice with roast duck and duck broth on the side. It is served with sliced chili peppers in soy sauce as a condiment.
khao-na-pet.thai: ข้าวหน้าเป็ด

khao-niao.notes: Khao niao is traditionally eaten using only the right hand. It is the staple food of Northern and Northeastern Thais.
khao-niao.thai: ข้าวเหนียว

khao-niao-mamuang.notes: Sticky rice cooked in sweetened thick coconut milk, served with slices of ripe mango. [2]
khao-niao-mamuang.thai: ข้าวเหนียวมะม่วง

khao-niao-sangkhaya.notes: Sticky rice served with an egg and coconut custard ( coconut jam ).
khao-niao-sangkhaya.thai: ข้าวเหนียวสังขยา

khao-nuea-op.notes: Rice with slices of baked beef, served with a spicy chili dip.
khao-nuea-op.thai: ข้าวเนื้ออบ

khao-phan-nga-muan.notes: Rolled khao phan with sesame seeds. Khao phan is a specialty from Uttaradit province. Rice flour is mixed with water and let to ferment overnight. The resulting batter is then spread out thinly over a cloth stretched out over a steamer, covered with a hood and let to steam for a few minutes. Rolled up it is served with a chili dip.
khao-phan-nga-muan.thai: ข้าวพันงาม้วน

khao-phan-phak.notes: Khao phan are thin, steamed rice sheets made from the fermented batter of rice flour mixed with water. Here it is served as a wrap for stir-fried vegetables.
khao-phan-phak.thai: ข้าวพันผัก

khao-phat.notes: Fried rice in Thailand can be made with different ingredients. Customarily served with fresh lime, cucumber, spring onions, and nam pla phrik (chili peppers in fish sauce).

khao-phat-amerikan.notes: American fried rice is rice fried with onion, tomato, raisins, and flavored with ketchup. It is often garnished with some sausage, fried chicken, and egg.
khao-phat-amerikan.thai: ข้าวผัดอเมริกัน

khao-phat-kaeng-khiao-wan.thai: ข้าวผัดแกงเขียวหวาน

khao-phat-kaphrao-mu.notes: Rice fried with a certain variety of Thai basil called kaphrao ( Ocimum tenuiflorum ), sliced pork, and chili peppers.
khao-phat-kaphrao-mu.thai: ข้าวผัดกะเพราหมู

khao-phat-nam-phrik-long-ruea.notes: Rice fried with Nam phrik long ruea (lit. "boat journey chili paste") and pieces of khai khem (salted duck's eggs). Fried, sliced, sweet Chinese sausage called kun chiang ( Thai : กุนเชียง ) are also served here with some sliced cucumber on the side.
khao-phat-nam-phrik-long-ruea.thai: ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกลงเรือ
khao-phat-nam-phrik-long-ruea.transcript_de: Khao phat nam phrik long ruea
khao-phat-nam-phrik-long-ruea.transcript_en: Khao phat nam phrik long ruea

khao-phat-nam-phrik-narok.notes: The name literally means "rice fried with chili paste from hell". The rice is fried with nam phrik narok , a very spicy chili paste made with fried catfish, grilled onion and garlic, grilled (dried) chili peppers, sugar, fish sauce, and shrimp paste. Here it is served with mu yang (grilled pork) and nam chim chaeo , a spicy dipping sauce.
khao-phat-nam-phrik-narok.thai: ข้าวผัดน้ำพริกนรก

khao-phat-namliap.notes: Rice fried with nam liap , the fruit of the Canarium album , also known as "Chinese olives".
khao-phat-namliap.thai: ข้าวผัดหนำเลี้ยบ

khao-soi-chang-mai.notes: Boiled as well as crispy fried egg noodles ( bami ) are served in a curry soup. The version with chicken is called khao soi kai , with beef it is called khao soi nuea .

khao-soi-mae-sai.notes: Khao soi Mae Sai is the name in Chiang Mai of a certain type of khao soi that is more common in Chiang Rai province , in the area along the border with Burma and Laos ( Mae Sai is a border town in Chiang Rai province). It is a spicy soup-like dish, similar to the broth used in khanom chin nam ngiao , containing soft, wide rice noodles, pork ribs, congealed pork blood, and minced pork. Tomatoes and fermented soy bean give it its specific taste. Sliced raw cabbage and bean sprouts are served on the side.
khao-soi-mae-sai.thai: ข้าวซอยแม่สาย

khao-soi-nam-na.notes: Somewhat similar to khao soi Mae Sai , this variant from the eastern part of Chiang Rai Province is made with wide rice noodles in a clear pork broth. A spoonful of nam phrik ong (a sauce made from minced pork, tomato, fermented soy bean or shrimp paste, and dried chili peppers) is heaped on top of the noodles ( nam na literally means "with sauce on top").
khao-soi-nam-na.thai: ข้าวซอยน้ำหน้า

khao-soi-noi-songkhrueang.notes: Colloquially also known as pizza doi (Thai: พิซซาดอย, literally: "mountain pizza"). This is a dish of Shan people . This version uses steamed egg and vegetables as the filling for the steamed rice wrap. The whole is dusted with crushed peanuts.
khao-soi-noi-songkhrueang.thai: ข้าวซอยน้อยทรงเครื่อง

khao-tom.notes: Boiled rice in a light broth, usually with minced pork, chicken, or fish. It is often eaten for breakfast.

khao-tom-kui.notes: Plain rice is cooked to a porridge and eaten as the staple together with a variety of side dishes.
khao-tom-kui.thai: ข้าวต้มกุ๊ย

khao-tom-mat.notes: The dish is made by wrapping sweet banana and sticky rice inside a banana leaf and then steaming it. The banana takes on a pink color after steaming.
khao-tom-mat.thai: ข้าวต้มมัด

khao-yam.notes: A type of Thai rice salad. Here it is shown unmixed, as served at a southern Thai eatery in Korat. This particular version used pomelo, bean sprouts, lime leaves, and toasted coconut flakes, and dried shrimp flakes with the rice.

kho-mu-yang-kratha-ron.notes: Kho mu yang kratha ron literally translates to "pork neck grilled on a hot skillet".
kho-mu-yang-kratha-ron.thai: คอหมูย่างกระทะร้อน

khua-chin-som-sai-khai.notes: Northern Thai pickled pork stir-fried with egg.
khua-chin-som-sai-khai.thai: คั่วจิ๊นส้มใส่ไข่

khua-ho.notes: Glass noodles are stir-fried with left-overs from other dishes. Unlike kaeng ho , this dish will not contain any left-over curry dishes. It was traditionally eaten at the end of a ceremony or festival. It is served here with pork rinds.

khua-kling.notes: A very spicy, dry fried curry made with chopped meat (usually beef, chicken, pork, or lamb) served with a large amount of shredded fresh kaffir lime leaves.

khua-kraduk.notes: A very spicy and, for Thai standards, "dry" curry with pork ribs and it is a Southern Thai speciality.
khua-kraduk.thai: คั่วกระดูกหมู

khua-no-mai-sai-mu.notes: Stir-fried bamboo shoots with pork. In this particular version, the pork is minced.
khua-no-mai-sai-mu.thai: คั่วหน่อไม้ใส่หมู

kluai-thot.notes: Deep-fried bananas in a light batter.

koi-pla.notes: Minced or finely chopped raw fish in spicy salad dressing. It is a popular raw fish dish in Isan and a common source of infection with Opisthorchis viverrini (Southeast Asian liver fluke ).

krating-daeng.notes: An energy drink and the origin of Red Bull .

kraya-sat.notes: Wafers or chunks of rice candy with beans and sesame. Often prepared as an offering to the monks .

kuai-tiao-nam.notes: A soup of wide rice noodles , often with minced pork, pork balls or fish balls .
kuai-tiao-nam.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวน้ำ

kuai-tiao-nuea-pueai.notes: A beef noodle soup with slices of very tender beef ( nuea pueay ).
kuai-tiao-nuea-pueai.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเนื้อเปื่อย

kuai-tiao-phat-khi-mao.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวผัดขี้เมา

kuai-tiao-rat-na.notes: Fried wide rice noodles with beef, pork, chicken, or seafood in a thickened gravy.
kuai-tiao-rat-na.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวราดหน้า

kuai-tiao-ruea.notes: Rice noodles with beef or pork (and sometimes offal) in a brown broth which contains cinnamon , star anise and sometimes blood. It is spicy and sour.
kuai-tiao-ruea.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเรือ

kuaichap.notes: Originally a Teochew Chinese dish ( Chinese : 粿汁 ), it is a soup of pork broth with rolled up rice noodle sheets (resulting in rolls about the size of Italian penne), pork intestines, "blood tofu", and boiled egg.

kung-chae-nampla.notes: A Thai salad made from fresh raw shrimp soaked in Thai fish sauce and served with sliced bitter gourd , mint, and a spicy sauce made with raw garlic, chilis, lime juice, sugar, and fresh cilantro/coriander.
kung-chae-nampla.thai: กุ้งแช่น้ำปลา

kung-ten.notes: A yam-style salad made with raw, and often still alive and "dancing", freshwater shrimp . Shrimp of the species Macrobrachium lanchesteri are often used. [3]

kung-thot-krathiam-phrik-thai.notes: Prawns fried with garlic and fresh peppercorns.
kung-thot-krathiam-phrik-thai.thai: กุ้งทอดกระเทียมพริกไทย
kung-thot-krathiam-phrik-thai.title_de: Deep fried prawns with garlic and pepper
kung-thot-krathiam-phrik-thai.title_en: Deep fried prawns with garlic and pepper

kung-yangkung-phao.notes: Grilled prawns are normally served with a nam chim , a spicy dipping sauce, made with mashed raw garlic and green bird's eye chili peppers, sugar, fish sauce, and lime juice.
kung-yangkung-phao.thai: กุ้งย่าง/กุ้งเผา

la-tiang.notes: It is an ancient Thai snack, because it appears in literature of King Rama II . It comprises shrimp, pork and peanut and wrapped by omelette to make a square shape.

lao-khao.notes: A distilled alcohol made from Thai rice , it is often a home-made moonshine .

lao-mae-khong.notes: Closer to a rum, it is distilled from sugarcane and rice.
lao-mae-khong.thai: เหล้าแม่โขง

lap-isan.notes: Northeastern style lap is a spicy and sour salad of minced raw or cooked meat (mainly pork, chicken or duck), shallots or onions, lime juice, fish sauce, chilis, ground roasted rice and mint.

lap-nuea.notes: Northern Thai lap is completely different from lap from northeastern Thailand. Northern Thai lap is made by mixing raw or cooked minced meat (mainly pork, beef, chicken or fish) with an elaborate mix of dry spices and herbs. The northern Thai lap does not contain lime juice or fish sauce. The version in the image is lap khua , meaning that the meat has been fried.

lap-nuea-dip.notes: A northern Thai lap -style salad of sliced raw beef (the version in the image also shows slices of raw beef tripe ) and ground, dried spices.
lap-nuea-dip.thai: ลาบเนื้อดิบ

leng-saap.notes: Spicy and sour pork spine soup.

lot-chong-nam-kathi.notes: Pandan -flavored rice flour noodles in sweetened coconut milk, similar to the Indonesian cendol .
lot-chong-nam-kathi.thai: ลอดช่องน้ำกะทิ

luk-chin-ping.notes: Meatballs made from fish, pork, beef or chicken are grilled on a stick and served with a spicy and tangy dipping sauce. The ones shown on the image are made with pork and beef. It is commonly sold from street stalls in Thailand.
luk-chin-ping.thai: ลูกชิ้นปิ้ง

mamuang-dong.notes: Pickled green mango is often eaten as a semi-sweet snack.

mamuang-nam-pla-wan.notes: Tart, unripe mango served with a sweet, salty and spicy dipping sauce made from shallots, fish sauce, dried chili peppers, dried shrimp, and palm sugar ( nam pla wan means "sweet fish sauce"). This is normally eaten as a snack on its own.
mamuang-nam-pla-wan.thai: มะม่วงน้ำปลาหวาน

mi-krop.notes: Deep fried rice vermicelli with a sweet and sour sauce.

miang-kham.notes: Dried shrimp and other ingredients wrapped in cha phlu (Thai: ชะพลู) leaves.

miang-pla.notes: Similar to Miang kham , the main ingredient for this wrap is deep-fried fish.

mu-daet-diao.notes: Deep-fried strips of sun dried pork, here with sesame seeds. A spicy dipping sauce (very often Sriracha sauce) is almost always provided with this dish.
mu-daet-diao.thai: หมูแดดเดียว

mu-kratha.notes: Mu kratha resembles a combination of a Korean barbecue and a Chinese hot pot . Meat (most often pork) is grilled in the center while the vegetables and other ingredients, such as fish balls , cook in the soup. It is served with a variety of nam chim (Thai dipping sauces).

mu-krop.notes: Cooked belly pork is first marinated and then deep fried until crispy. Often used sliced in vegetables stir fries.

mu-krop-phat-kaphrao.notes: Slices of crispy grilled pork are stirred-fried with holy basil. This particular version is served with khai dao (fried egg) which had the egg yolk removed before frying and then added on later.
mu-krop-phat-kaphrao.thai: หมูกรอบผัดกะเพรา
mu-krop-phat-kaphrao.title_de: Stir-fried holy basil with crispy pork
mu-krop-phat-kaphrao.title_en: Stir-fried holy basil with crispy pork

mu-manao.notes: Sliced grilled pork with a dressing ( nam chim ) of mashed garlic, green bird's eye chili peppers, sugar, fish sauce, and lime juice. Here it is served with additional sliced bird's eye chili peppers and raw garlic on a bed of ice-water chilled sliced raw phak khana (Chinese broccoli)

mu-nam-tok.notes: A very spicy salad made with pork ( mu ) and somewhat identical to lap , except that the meat is cut into thin strips rather than minced.

mu-phat-sato.notes: Sliced pork stir-fried with sato (the beans of the Parkia speciosa , also known as "stink bean" or "bitter bean"), onion, garlic, fish sauce, chili peppers, and oyster sauce.
mu-phat-sato.thai: หมูผัดสะตอ

mu-phat-sato-phak-tai.notes: A spicy, southern Thai, version of mu phat sato where the pork and "stink beans" are fried with a copious amount of chili peppers and chili paste.
mu-phat-sato-phak-tai.thai: หมูผัดสะตอภาคใต้

mu-ruam-luak-chim.notes: This dish consist of several types of pork (intestines, liver, and other cuts) which have been shortly blanched in boiling water or stock and then served with fried garlic, spring onions and a spicy dipping sauce.
mu-ruam-luak-chim.thai: หมูรวมลวกจิ้ม

mu-thot-krathiam.thai: หมูทอดกระเทียม

mu-wan.notes: Sliced pork is simmered or fried with sugar and soy sauce until the sauce is reduced and coats the meat.

mu-yang.notes: Originally from the Isan region of Thailand, the fatty parts of belly pork, together with the skin, are preferred over lean meat. It is served with nam chim chaeo , a spicy dipping sauce made with dried chili peppers, and roasted sticky rice.

naem-khluk.notes: Naem sausage (pork fermented with sticky rice) [4] is mixed with boiled rice and then deep-fried. The salad is made by crumbling the deep-fried balls and mixing in sliced shallots, dried chilis, fish sauce and lime juice. It is served with raw vegetables and herbs.

nam-bai-bua-bok.notes: A refreshing drink made from the leaves of the Asiatic Pennywort ( Centella asiatica ).
nam-bai-bua-bok.thai: น้ำใบบัวบก

nam-chim-chaeo.notes: It is a sticky, sweet and spicy dipping sauce made with dried chili peppers, fish sauce, palm sugar, lime juice, and coarsely roasted sticky rice. Often served as a dip with mu yang (grilled pork).
nam-chim-chaeo.thai: น้ำจิ้มแจ่ว

nam-chim-kai.notes: A very common all-round chili dipping sauce with the consistency of a thick syrup, it is medium spicy and very sweet. Often used as a dipping sauce for grilled chicken ( kai means "chicken"), it can also be used as a generic chili sauce for other dishes. It forms the base of a few other types of nam chim , such as nam chim thot man pla ("dipping sauce for deep-fried fish cakes").
nam-chim-kai.thai: น้ำจิ้มไก่

nam-chim-paesa.notes: A spicy dipping sauce eaten with steamed fish wrapped in raw lettuce or cabbage.
nam-chim-paesa.thai: น้ำจิ้มแป๊ะซะ

nam-chim-sate.notes: A peanut sauce which is normally served with satay .
nam-chim-sate.thai: น้ำจิ้มสะเต๊ะ

nam-dok-anchan.notes: A refreshing drink made from Clitoria ternatea flower flavored with sugar served with ice.
nam-dok-anchan.thai: น้ำดอกอัญชัน

nam-manao.notes: A refreshing drink made from lime juice flavored with sugar and a pinch of salt served with ice.

nam-phan.notes: Resembling a slush puppie laced with alcohol, this drink is popular with students. Nam means liquid or water, phan is derived from the English word " punch ": a beverage based on fruit and often containing alcohol.

nam-phrik-i-ke.notes: A northern Thai chili paste made with chili peppers, sliced aubergine, pork rinds, and fermented shrimp paste.
nam-phrik-i-ke.thai: น้ำพริกอีเก๋

nam-phrik-kapi.notes: A pungent chili dip made with shrimp paste , pounded dried shrimp, bird's eye chili peppers, garlic, lime juice, fish sauce, palm sugar, and optionally, pea sized aubergines ; most often eaten as part of the dish called Nam phrik pla thu .
nam-phrik-kapi.thai: น้ำพริกกะปิ

nam-phrik-kapi-kap-pla-thu-thot.notes: Fried pla thu served with nam phrik kapi , a pungent dip made mainly from shrimp paste and chili peppers, and raw, steamed or fried vegetables (often pieces of cha-om omelette). It is eaten with khanom chin (Thai rice noodles) or steamed rice. Although the name of this dish is often shortened to nam phrik pla thu , this refers to a certain type of chili paste in which pla thu is used as an ingredient.
nam-phrik-kapi-kap-pla-thu-thot.thai: น้ำพริกกะปิกับปลาทูทอด
nam-phrik-kapi-kap-pla-thu-thot.transcript_de: Nam phrik kapi kap pla thu thot
nam-phrik-kapi-kap-pla-thu-thot.transcript_en: Nam phrik kapi kap pla thu thot

nam-phrik-kha.notes: A Northern Thai fried chili paste containing ( kha ). It is often eaten, as seen here, with steamed het nang fa (Thai script: เห็ดนางฟ้า; lit. "fairy mushroom"; Pleurotus pulmonarius).
nam-phrik-kha.thai: น้ำพริกข่า

nam-phrik-khaep-mu.notes: A northern Thai chili paste of mashed grilled green chili peppers, deep-fried pork rinds, fresh garlic, and salt.
nam-phrik-khaep-mu.thai: น้ำพริกแคบหมู

nam-phrik-long-ruea.notes: The name means "chili paste for in a boat" as it was often eaten while travelling the rivers of Thailand by boat. A sweet, savoury and spicy chili dip, it is served together with fresh vegetables, salted egg and sweet pork. This version also included khamin khao ("white curcuma") and the slightly sour and bitter leaves of makok ( Spondias mombin )
nam-phrik-long-ruea.thai: น้ำพริกลงเรือ

nam-phrik-num.notes: A paste of pounded roasted large green chili peppers, roasted shallots, roasted garlic, coriander leaves, lime juice, and fish sauce that is eaten with steamed and raw vegetables, khaep mu (crispy pork rind), and sticky rice.
nam-phrik-num.thai: น้ำพริกหนุ่ม

nam-phrik-ong.notes: Resembling a thick Bolognese sauce , it is made with dried chili peppers, minced pork, and tomato that is eaten with steamed vegetables, raw vegetables, and sticky rice.
nam-phrik-ong.thai: น้ำพริกอ่อง

nam-phrik-phao.notes: A sweet roasted chili paste, often used as an ingredient in Tom yam or when frying meat or seafood, and also popular as a spicy "jam" on bread or toasted bread.
nam-phrik-phao.thai: น้ำพริกเผา

nam-phrik-pla-chi.notes: A chili paste made with grilled fish, roasted chili peppers, roasted shallots, and roasted garlic, lemongrass, and shrimp paste. It is normally served with both steamed and raw vegetables or other leaves.
nam-phrik-pla-chi.thai: น้ำพริกปลาจี่

nam-sup.notes: This is a clear broth, usually served together with khao man kai (chicken rice), khao mok (Thai biryani ), khao kha mu (pork trotter simmered in soy sauce served with rice), khao na pet (red roast duck on rice), or khao mu daeng ( red roast pork on rice). The broth can be made from chicken or pork, or it can be wholly vegetarian. The version served with duck is usually made from duck bones. It will often contain sliced hua chai thao (white radish ; also known as phak kat hua in Thai) and hua chai po khem (a Chinese ingredient of dried and salted chopped turnip). Garlic, ginger, and pepper are often used as additional ingredients. It is most often garnished with fresh coriander leaves or spring onion.

nam-takhrai.notes: A refreshing drink made from lemongrass. It can be served either hot or with ice.

nang-kai-thot.notes: Crispy, deep-fried chicken skin that can be eaten as a snack or together with chili pastes or salads.
nang-kai-thot.thai: หนังไก่ทอด

no-mai-farang-phat-kung.notes: Green asparagus stir-fried with prawns, garlic, sliced chili peppers, fish sauce, and oyster sauce.
no-mai-farang-phat-kung.thai: หน่อไม้ฝรั่งผัดกุ้ง

no-yat-sai-thot.notes: A northern Thai speciality of deep-fried bamboo shoots with a filling of minced pork.
no-yat-sai-thot.thai: หน่อยัดไส้ทอด

nom-yen.notes: A drink made from sala syrup and hot milk.

nuea-daet-diao-kaphrao-thot.notes: Deep-fried strips of sun dried beef and with crispy fried holy basil .
nuea-daet-diao-kaphrao-thot.thai: เนื้อแดดเดียวกะเพราทอด

nuea-khem-thot.notes: Salted and sun-dried beef that has been deep-fried before serving.
nuea-khem-thot.thai: เนื้อเค็มทอด

nuea-phat-bai-yira.notes: Besides beef and basil, other ingredients are garlic, chili peppers, light soy sauce, and fish sauce. African basil leaves have a slight anise taste.
nuea-phat-bai-yira.thai: เนื้อผัดใบยี่หร่า

nuea-thup.notes: Beef is pounded after grilling, and served with a chili dip.

nuea-yang-nam-tok.notes: With a similar "dressing" as larb , this dish is made with sliced grilled beef. "Nam tok" means "waterfall" in Thai and it is thought that the meat juices should run out from the meat like a waterfall.
nuea-yang-nam-tok.thai: เนื้อย่างน้ำตก

oliang.notes: A sweet Thai black ice coffee . The name is of Teochew origin where "o" means black, and "liang" means cold.

paeng-nom-yang-nuea.notes: Grilled cow udders, served with a chili dip.
paeng-nom-yang-nuea.thai: แป้งนมย่างอมเนื้อ

pak-boong-fai-daeng.notes: Morning-glory (a.k.a. water spinach ) stir fried with yellow bean sauce , garlic, and chili peppers. It is a very popular vegetable dish in Thailand.
pak-boong-fai-daeng.thai: ผักบุ้งไฟแดง

pam-khai-mot.notes: Grilled banana leaf cups containing a mixture of ant eggs, chicken eggs and some salt. After grilling the dish is sprinkled with chopped spring onion and pepper. The ant eggs make the dish much more creamy. It can also be eaten as a snack.

pathongko.notes: The Thai version of the Chinese crullers called youtiao , they tend to be smaller than the Chinese original. Most often eaten with sweetened condensed milk or with Thai coconut jam , they can also be served with chok , Thai rice congee .

phak-khana-nam-man-hoi.notes: Originally a Chinese dish, it has been adapted to Thai taste by adding fish sauce to the recipe and by omitting the ginger. Here it is made with fried shiitake mushroom.
phak-khana-nam-man-hoi.thai: ผักคะน้าน้ำมันหอย
phak-khana-nam-man-hoi.title_de: Stir-fried Chinese kale with oyster sauce
phak-khana-nam-man-hoi.title_en: Stir-fried Chinese kale with oyster sauce

phat-buap.notes: Stir-fried luffa (sponge gourd) with pork/shrimp and egg or just egg.

phat-dok-hom.notes: Stir-fried onion flowers with pork and pork liver.
phat-dok-hom.title_de: Stir-fried onion flower stem with pork/liver
phat-dok-hom.title_en: Stir-fried onion flower stem with pork/liver

phat-kaphrao.notes: Minced beef, pork, chicken, or whole prawns stir fried with Thai holy basil, chili peppers, garlic, and soy sauce.
phat-kaphrao.title_de: Stir-fired minced meat with thai holy basil
phat-kaphrao.title_en: Stir-fired minced meat with thai holy basil

phat-khana-mu-krop.notes: Khana ( gailan or Chinese kale) is stir fried with crispy pork ( mu krop ), garlic, oyster sauce, soy sauce, peppercorns, and (optionally) sliced chili peppers.
phat-khana-mu-krop.thai: ผัดคะน้าหมูกรอบ
phat-khana-mu-krop.title_de: Stir-fried Chinese kale with crispy pork
phat-khana-mu-krop.title_en: Stir-fried Chinese kale with crispy pork

phat-khanaeng-mu.notes: Stir-fried khanaeng with pork, garlic, oyster sauce, fish sauce, and white pepper. Khanaeng are the sprouts of Chinese broccoli and grow from the root after the main stem has been harvested. The taste is in between Brussels sprouts and kale , and very sweet.
phat-khanaeng-mu.thai: ผัดแขนงหมู

phat-mama.notes: Mama ( Thai : มาม่า ) is the most popular brand of instant noodles in Thailand and the brand name is commonly used, instead of the generic bami kueng samret rup ( Thai : บะหมี่กึ่งสำเร็จรูป ), to designate instant noodles. The particular version in the image has been stir-fried " drunken noodle "-style.

phat-naem-sai-khai.notes: Naem sausage (made from fermented raw pork skin and sticky rice) stir fried with egg.
phat-naem-sai-khai.thai: ผัดแหนมใส่ไข่

phat-no-mai-sai-khai.thai: ผัดหน่อไม้ใส่ไข่

phat-phak-ruam.notes: Stir fried combination of vegetables depending on availability and preference, but it is usually fried with oyster sauce .

phat-phrik-khing.notes: Sliced pork fried with asparagus beans and kaffir lime leaves in a sweet chili paste. Sometimes red curry paste is used instead of the phrik khing chili paste.
phat-phrik-khing.title_de: Stir-fried pork with Thai chili peppers
phat-phrik-khing.title_en: Stir-fried pork with Thai chili peppers

phat-si-io.notes: Usually wide rice noodles fried with chicken or pork, and soy sauce.

phat-thai.notes: Stir fried medium size rice noodles ( sen lek ) with fish sauce, sugar, lime juice or tamarind pulp, ground peanuts, egg, bean sprouts, and Chinese chives ( kuichai ), combined with shrimp.

phat-wun-sen.notes: Glass noodles are stir-fried with egg and vegetables, and a variety of ingredients such as meat, seafood, or with vegetarian alternatives.
phat-wun-sen.thai: ผัดวุ้นเส้น

phat-yot-fak-maeo.notes: Yot sayongte, which is also known in Thailand as yot fak meao ( yot meaning " shoots "), are the young vines and leaves of a certain type of melon ( chayote , originally from Central America) which in Thailand grows mainly in the mountains up north. These greens have a very sweet taste and combine extremely well with oyster sauce.
phat-yot-fak-maeo.thai: ผัดยอดฟักแม้ว

phla-kung.notes: A spicy salad of prawns, sliced lemongrass, culantro or other herbs, and shallots , with a dressing of lime juice, sweet chilli paste ( Nam phrik phao – optional), fish sauce, pounded garlic and bird's eye chili . The version shown in the image also contained minced pork.

phla-mu.notes: A spicy salad of sliced grilled pork, sliced lemongrass, mint, culantro (optional) and shallots , with a dressing of lime juice, sweet chili paste ( Nam phrik phao – optional), fish sauce, pounded garlic and bird's eye chili .

phla-nuea-makhuea-on.notes: A Thai salad made with medium rare beef and Thai aubergines. The sliced, raw eggplants are mixed in with the warm beef to soften them ( makhuea on means "soft aubergine"). This particular version of the salad was served with a nam tok -style dressing.
phla-nuea-makhuea-on.thai: พล่าเนื้อมะเขืออ่อน

phrik-nam-pla.notes: Colloquially called phrik nam pla , it is a standard sauce served with every Thai buffet style meal, fried rice or fried noodles, and used as a kind of "salt". It is made by mixing fish sauce with some lime juice, chopped bird's eye chili peppers, and often also sliced garlic.
phrik-nam-pla.thai: น้ำปลาพริก

phunim-phat-phong-kari.notes: Deep-fried pieces of soft-shell crab which have been stir-fried with egg and curry powder.
phunim-phat-phong-kari.thai: ปูนิ่มผัดผงกะหรี่
phunim-phat-phong-kari.title_de: Stir-fried soft-shelled crab with curry powder
phunim-phat-phong-kari.title_en: Stir-fried soft-shelled crab with curry powder

pik-kai-sot-sai-thot.notes: Deep fried, partially deboned chicken wings, stuffed usually with minced pork.
pik-kai-sot-sai-thot.thai: ปีกไก่สอดไส้ทอด

pla-buang.notes: Cuts of Giant snakehead fish ( pla chado ) are first salted and sun-dried for three days, and then deep-fried. This dish is somewhat similar to pla chado daet diao from central Thailand but there the fish is only dried for only one day, making the taste less intense.

pla-duk-phat-phet.notes: Slices of catfish (most often pre-fried) are stir-fried in a sauce made with red curry paste. The pea eggplant feature in this dish is for added taste and texture.
pla-duk-phat-phet.thai: ปลาดุกผัดเผ็ด
pla-duk-phat-phet.title_de: Stir-fired sliced catfish with red curry paste
pla-duk-phat-phet.title_en: Stir-fired sliced catfish with red curry paste

pla-kaphong-phat-khuen-chai.notes: Barramundi (often called "sea bass" in Thailand) stir-fried with Chinese celery, light soy sauce, garlic, ginger, and fermented soy beans.
pla-kaphong-phat-khuen-chai.thai: ปลากะพงผัดขึ้นฉ่าย

pla-krai-thot-krathiam.notes: Deep-fried pla krai (" Clown Knifefish ") and garlic. It is served with a spicy dipping sauce on the side made from coriander root, lime juice, fresh bird's eye chili peppers, garlic, sugar, and fish sauce.
pla-krai-thot-krathiam.thai: ปลากรายทอดกระเทียม

pla-muek-phat-phrik-phao.notes: Squid stir-fried with sweet and mild chili paste ( nam phrik phao ), onion, garlic, spring onion, and sliced large red chili peppers. Paprika can be used instead of chili peppers if a milder version is preferred.
pla-muek-phat-phrik-phao.thai: ปลาหมึกผัดพริกเผา

pla-muek-yang.thai: ปลาหมึกย่าง

pla-nin-thot-samun-phrai.notes: Deep-fried pla nin ("Nile Tilipia") served with deep-fried herbs such as lemongrass, kaffir lime leaves, garlic, and fingerroot ( Boesenbergia rotunda ). A chili-lime dip is served on the side as a condiment.
pla-nin-thot-samun-phrai.thai: ปลานิลทอดสมุนไพร

pla-nueng-manao.notes: Steamed fish which is drenched in a spicy garlic, chili sauce, chicken stock and lime juice dressing.
pla-nueng-manao.thai: ปลานึ่งมะนาว

pla-ping-top.notes: Traditional grilled fish of Tai Dam people in Loei .Catch the fish to clean the scales, then peck the fish along the back of the spine instead of the belly so that the soft fish will fold up more easily and the spice stuffed in the belly of the fish exposed to embers will give fragrance to infuse the fish meat.

pla-sam-rot.notes: Deep fried fish with a sweet, tangy, and spicy tamarind sauce.

pla-sam-thap.notes: Fish prepared in 3 different ways: on the left of the image is pla sam rot (deep-fried served with a tangy sweet chili sauce), in the middle pla nueng manao (steamed fish with a raw garlic, lime and chili sauce), and on the right pla thot krathiam (deep-fried fish with deep-fried garlic).

pla-thot.notes: A simple deep-fried fish, most often served with a spicy dipping sauce. The fish in this image is pla nin , a Nile Tilapia .

pla-thot-khamin.notes: Typical for southern Thai cuisine, this deep-fried fish has first been marinated in a spice mixture which includes a large amount of turmeric ( khamin ). In addition, this particular version was topped with crispy deep-fried chopped garlic and turmeric. It is often served with raw vegetables on the side, and a spicy dipping sauce.
pla-thot-khamin.thai: ปลาทอดขมิ้น

pla-wong-thot.notes: Deep-fried pla wong (literally meaning "circle fish"): fish which have first been cut open, arranged into a circle and then sun-dried. Here it is served Southern Thai style with a spoonful of a deep-fried mix of minced garlic, galangal, and turmeric.

pu-cha.notes: A mixture of cooked crab meat, pork, garlic, and pepper, fried deeply inside the crab shells and usually served with nam chim buoy ( Thai : น้ำจิ้มบ๋วย , plum sauce). Instead of being fried in the crab shell, it is also sometimes served as patties.

pu-ong.notes: A northern Thai speciality that is eaten as a pungent dipping sauce for sticky rice. It is made by collecting the "fat" of rice field crabs ( Parathelphusidae ) and grilling this inside the crab shell.
pu-ong.thai: ปูอ่อง or อ่องปู

roti.notes: In Thailand, Roti is eaten primarily with Southern Thai curries. It is also a popular street food dessert that is topped with sweetened condensed milk.

roti-kluai.notes: Sliced banana and beaten eggs are fried inside a thin sheet of dough, then cut and served with sweetened condensed milk or sugar.

roti-sai-mai.notes: An extremely sweet kind of cotton candy which is wrapped inside small, thin pancakes.
roti-sai-mai.thai: โรตีสายไหม

ruam-mit.notes: A chilled sweet snack/dessert with a mix of ingredients, such as sweetened chestnuts, jackfruit, lotus root, tapioca, and lot chong , in sweetened coconut milk.

sa-nuea.notes: A northern Thai speciality, made with blanched medium rare, thinly sliced beef. Other ingredients for this dish are the elaborate phrik lap Lanna spices-and-chilli mix, onions, some broth, and fresh herbs.

sa-nuea-sadung.notes: A northern Thai speciality, made with sauteed medium rare, thinly sliced beef. Other ingredients for this dish are the elaborate phrik lap Lanna spices-and-chili mix, onions, some broth, and fresh herbs such as kraphao (holy basil) or phak phai ( Vietnamese coriander ) although this particular version was made using saranae ( spearmint ). This particular version also contained nam phia , the partially digested contents from the first of the four stomachs of cattle, for added flavour. [5]
sa-nuea-sadung.thai: ส้าเนื้อสะดุ้ง

saeng-som.notes: A Thai rum which has been distilled since 1977.

sai-krok-isan.notes: Grilled, fermented pork and sticky rice sausage, originally from the Isan region of Thailand. It can be shaped like a sausage as in the image, or as round balls . It is also often eaten as a snack at festivals and fairs, and served together with sliced ginger, bird's eye chili peppers, and raw cabbage.
sai-krok-isan.thai: ไส้กรอกอีสาน

sai-mu-ping.thai: ไส้หมูปิ้ง

sai-ua.notes: A grilled sausage of ground pork mixed with spices and herbs, and which is often served with chopped fresh ginger and chili peppers at a meal.

sakhu-sai-mu.notes: In Thailand tapioca balls with pork filling are call sakhu sai mu . Sakhu sai mu is a kind of snack which is very famous in Thailand and found at street stalls and markets. It is a dumpling which consists of a flour ball with a pork filling. Most people in Thailand eat it with khao kriap pak mo .
sakhu-sai-mu.thai: สาคูไส้หมู

sakhu-thua-dam.notes: Tapioca pearls and black beans (one of the vigna cultivars) with sweetened coconut milk and the flesh of a young coconut.
sakhu-thua-dam.thai: สาคูถั่วดำ

sangkhaya-fak-thong.notes: Steamed pumpkin with an egg-and-coconut custard filling, similar to the coconut jam from Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines.
sangkhaya-fak-thong.thai: สังขยาฟักทอง

sapaketti-phat-khi-mao.notes: A Thai fusion dish where the name literally means spaghetti fried "shit-drunk" ( khi mao = extremely drunk). An explanation is that any dish fried this way is easy to make, spicy, and uses whatever ingredients are available at that time; great after a night out drinking when still hungry.
sapaketti-phat-khi-mao.thai: สปาเกตตีผัดขี้เมา

sate.notes: Marinated beef, chicken, or pork grilled on bamboo skewers and usually served with nam chim sate (peanut sauce) and achat (pickled cucumber).

satho.notes: A traditional rice wine from the Isan region.

si-khrong-mu-thot.notes: Deep-fried pork ribs. The version in the image however, had first been boiled, then marinated, then deep-fried with garlic, and then again stir-fried with a sweet and tangy tamarind sauce just before serving.
si-khrong-mu-thot.thai: ซี่โครงหมูทอด

som-tam.notes: Som tam which contains peanuts, is the Central Thai dish that became famous internationally

som-tam-khai-khem.notes: A variation of the standard papaya som tam with salted eggs.
som-tam-khai-khem.thai: ส้มตำไข่เค็ม

som-tam-pu.notes: Green papaya salad with brined rice paddy crabs.

sot-si-racha.notes: It is a hot sauce made from sun-ripened chili peppers, vinegar, garlic, sugar, and salt. It is commonly known in Thailand as sot Si Racha ( sot is the Thai pronunciation of the English word "sauce"), but also as nam chim Si Racha or nam phrik Si Racha . The name is derived from the seaside town of Si Racha .
sot-si-racha.thai: ซอสศรีราชา

suea-rong-hai.notes: Suea rong hai literally means "weeping tiger". It is grilled marinated beef which is eaten with vegetables and Nam chim chaeo dipping sauce.
suea-rong-hai.thai: เสือร้องไห้

suki.notes: A Thai variant of the Chinese hot pot , it is mainly eaten as a meal on its own.

tam-khanun.notes: A spicy Northern Thai salad made with boiled green whole jackfruit which has been mashed with a mortar and pestle, and minced pork. It is normally eaten with sticky rice and (as seen on the image) with khaep mu (pork cracklings).

tam-maak-hoong.notes: This version is more spicy, salty, and less sweet of som tam that contains pla ra (a sauce of fermented fish), and very often also brined rice paddy crabs, and makok (the fruit of the Spondias mombin ) besides the usual ingredients for som tam . It does not however contain peanuts.
tam-maak-hoong.thai: ตำหมากหุ่ง

tam-makhuea.notes: Chopped and then pounded grilled long green eggplant ( makhuea yao ; Thai : มะเขือยาว ), grilled green chili peppers, raw garlic and salt put in a banana leaf package mixed together with hard-boiled egg. It's a speciality of Northern Thailand where it is traditionally eaten with sticky rice .

tam-mamuang.notes: A som tam style salad with tangy unripe mango "au Julienne" as its main ingredient. The version in the image contains pla haeng thot , deep-fried sun-dried anchovies.

tam-maphrao-on-sen-mi-krop.notes: A som tam style salad made with the meat of a young coconut and served with crispy deep-fried thin Chinese rice noodles.
tam-maphrao-on-sen-mi-krop.thai: ตำมะพร้าวอ่อนเส้นหมี่กรอบ
tam-maphrao-on-sen-mi-krop.transcript_de: Tam maphrao on sen mi krop
tam-maphrao-on-sen-mi-krop.transcript_en: Tam maphrao on sen mi krop

tam-mu-yo.notes: A spicy Thai salad made with mu yo , a Thai pork sausage which is often also described in Thailand as "Vietnamese sausage". The dressing is somewhat similar to that of som tam .

tam-phonlamai-ruam.notes: The fruits used in this particular salad show the fusion aspect of Thai cuisine, as it incorporates "modern" (for Thais) fruit such as apples and grapes besides traditional fruit such as pineapple and guava. The dressing is made with pounded garlic, sugar, chili peppers, dried shrimp, lime juice and fish sauce, and is similar to that of som tam .
tam-phonlamai-ruam.thai: ตำผลไม้รวม

tam-som-o-nam-pu.notes: It is a spicy pomelo salad which uses crab extract as a flavouring. This black sauce is achieved by pounding pu na ("ricefield crabs", Somanniathelphusa ) to a pulp, straining the juices which are then boiled and reduced until the sauce becomes as thick as molasses.
tam-som-o-nam-pu.thai: ตำส้มโอน้ำปู

tap-kai-phat-phrik-sot.notes: Chicken liver fried with young (mainly green) chili peppers, light soy sauce, oyster sauce, onion, spring onion, black pepper, and garlic. Here it is served with rice and a fried egg ( khai dao ).
tap-kai-phat-phrik-sot.thai: ตับไก่ผัดพริกสด
tap-kai-phat-phrik-sot.title_de: Stir-fried chicken liver with green peppers
tap-kai-phat-phrik-sot.title_en: Stir-fried chicken liver with green peppers

that-khai.notes: The Thai version of the Portuguese pastel de nata .

thong-yip.notes: Thong yip is made from egg yolks like foi thong . The difference is that instead of being thread-like, thong yip are shaped like flowers.

thot-man-khaophot.notes: Deep-fried cakes made with corn and herbs in a batter and served with a sweet chili sauce
thot-man-khaophot.thai: ทอดมันข้าวโพด

thot-man-kung.notes: Another popular variety of thot man where minced shrimp or prawn is used. Plum sauce is commonly provided.
thot-man-kung.thai: ทอดมันกุ้ง

thot-man-pla.notes: Deep fried patties of minced fish mixed with red curry paste, finely chopped yardlong beans ( tua fak yao ), and finely shredded leaves of kaffir lime ( makrut ). Knife fish (pla krai) is popularly used. For this variety of thot man, a sweet & hot similar to chicken chili sauce is provided usually mixed with chopped pieces of cucumber, crushed peanuts, and topped with phak chi .

thot-man-pu.notes: Deep fried patties of minced crab meat. Plum sauce is commonly provided.

thua-ngok-pla-khem.notes: A stir-fried dish of mung bean sprouts, salted fish, chili peppers, and garlic.
thua-ngok-pla-khem.thai: ถั่วงอกปลาเค็ม
thua-ngok-pla-khem.title_de: Stir-fried bean sprouts with salted fish
thua-ngok-pla-khem.title_en: Stir-fried bean sprouts with salted fish

thung-thong.notes: Small, crispy, deep-fried pastry purses filled with a mixture of minced chicken or pork together with minced prawns, mushroom and water chestnut , and served with sweet plum sauce or Thai sweet chili sauce.

tod-mun-hua-plee.notes: Tod Mun Hua Plee is one of the individual dishes in Thailand. It is made from banana blossom which is the flower of banana.
tod-mun-hua-plee.thai: ทอดมันหัวปลี

tom-chuet.notes: A light vegetable, chicken or pork broth with vegetables and celery, to which minced pork, soft tofu, seaweed, glass noodles , and mushroom can be added. This soup can also be called Kaeng chuet ( Thai : แกงจืดวุ้นเส้น ).

tom-kha-kai.notes: A mild to spicy soup with coconut milk, ( kha ) and chicken. Mushrooms can be added to the chicken or substitute it. [1]

tom-khlong.notes: It is a spicy and sour soup somewhat similar to Tom yam. The sourness however does not derive from lime juice but through the use of tamarind juice. The version in the image contains fried smoked fish, tomato, and mushrooms. [1]

tom-mara.notes: A clear soup made with bitter melon (also known as bitter gourd; Momordica charantia ) of Chinese origin. It is often stuffed with minced pork or with minced pork mixed with glass noodles as on this image. The full name of the latter version would then be tom mara yat sai mu sap wunsen .

tom-phak-kat-dong-mu.notes: A soup of boiled pickled Chinese cabbage and pork ribs. This dish is Chinese in origin.
tom-phak-kat-dong-mu.thai: ต้มผักกาดดองหมู

tom-saep.notes: A spicy soup made with stewed meat (usually pork, chicken or beef), roasted fresh herbs and spices, ground roasted rice, and generous amounts of lime juice and fresh herbs just before serving.

tom-som-kraduk-mu.notes: Tom som translates to "sour soup". This particular version is a basic one with only pork ribs ( kraduk mu ) and it derives its sourness from lime juice. Other types of tom som can also use tamarind for acidity, or a combination of both lime and tamarind, and can be made from a multitude of ingredients: meats as well as seafood, and vegetables. [1]
tom-som-kraduk-mu.thai: ต้มส้มกระดูกหมู

tom-yam.notes: A hot and sour broth made from lemon grass , kaffir lime leaves, dried chili peppers, and lime juice, usually with prawns ( Tom yam kung ) or chicken ( Tom yam kai ). [1] [2]

tom-yam-boran.notes: Tom yam boran is noodles served in a thick spicy sour sauce or broth, with crushed dried chili peppers, chopped peanuts, and blanched vegetables such as bean sprouts. This version is bami mu tom yam boran : with egg noodles and pork.
tom-yam-boran.thai: ต้มยำโบราณ

tom-yuea-phai.notes: It is a clear broth with, amongst other ingredients, yuea phai ("bamboo fungus"; Phallus indusiatus )
tom-yuea-phai.thai: ต้มเยื่อไผ่

tua-mai-thot.notes: Crispy, deep-fried pupae of silkworms . This dish is most often eaten as a snack in order to go with any drink.

yam-bai-cha.notes: A spicy Thai salad made with young, fresh tea leaves.

yam-chin-kai.notes: A curry dish from Northern Thailand containing chicken. The version in the image also contains sliced banana flower.

yam-hoi-khraeng.notes: A spicy Thai salad made with blood cockles .

yam-hu-mu.notes: It is a salad made with thinly sliced, boiled pig's ears, the version in the image also contained fresh mint, lime juice, shallots, lemon grass, fish sauce and sugar.

yam-hua-pli-thot.notes: A spicy Thai yam-style salad with deep-fried slices of banana blossom as its main ingredient.
yam-hua-pli-thot.thai: ยำหัวปลีทอด

yam-khai-dao.notes: A spicy Thai salad made with fried egg ( khai dao ).

yam-khamin-khao-kung.notes: A spicy Thai salad made with finely sliced ( au Julienne ) "white curcuma" (probably Curcuma zedoaria ), shredded coconut, cooked prawns, sliced shallots, dried chilis, fresh green bird's eye chili peppers, roasted cashew nuts, and crispy fried onion rings.
yam-khamin-khao-kung.thai: ยำขมิ้นขาวกุ้ง

yam-kun-chiang.notes: A Thai salad made with a sweet dried pork sausage called kun chiang . This sausage is of Chinese origin. This dish is often eaten with plain rice congee ( khao tom kui ; Thai : ข้าวต้มกุ๊ย ).
yam-kun-chiang.thai: ยำกุนเชียง

yam-mu-krop.notes: A Thai salad made with crispy belly pork ( mu krop ).

yam-mu-yo.notes: A spicy yam-style Thai salad with mu yo ( Vietnamese sausage ).

yam-mu-yo-thot-khai-dao.notes: A spicy Thai salad made with crispy fried mu yo (Vietnamese sausage) and khai dao (fried egg).
yam-mu-yo-thot-khai-dao.thai: ยำหมูยอทอดไข่ดาว
yam-mu-yo-thot-khai-dao.transcript_de: Yam mu yo thot khai dao
yam-mu-yo-thot-khai-dao.transcript_en: Yam mu yo thot khai dao

yam-naem-khao-khot.notes: A Thai salad made of crumbled, crispy-fried curried rice balls (similar to a spherical croquette), fermented pork sausage, shallots, green chili peppers or dried chili flakes, peanuts, lime juice, fish sauce, and onion.
yam-naem-khao-khot.thai: ยำแหนมข้าวทอด

yam-naem-sot.notes: A Thai salad containing sausage made from fermented raw pork and sticky rice ( naem sausage).

yam-no-mai.notes: A Northern Thai salad made with strips of boiled bamboo shoots, shallots, herbs, fish sauce, lime juice, and chili peppers.

yam-no-mai-sai-nam-pu.notes: A northern Thai salad made with boiled bamboo shoots and a thick paste made from the rice paddy crabs.
yam-no-mai-sai-nam-pu.thai: ยำหน่อไม้ใส่น้ำปู
yam-no-mai-sai-nam-pu.transcript_de: Yam no mai sai nam pu
yam-no-mai-sai-nam-pu.transcript_en: Yam no mai sai nam pu

yam-nuea-yang.notes: A spicy salad of grilled beef, shallots, and Thai celery or spearmint.
yam-nuea-yang.thai: ยำเนื้อย่าง

yam-phak-khut.notes: A salad of edible fern shoots ( Diplazium esculentum ) and pork.

yam-pla-duk-fu.notes: Crispy fried shredded pla duk (catfish) served with a spicy and tangy green mango salad.
yam-pla-duk-fu.thai: ยำปลาดุกฟู

yam-pla-khem.notes: A Thai salad ( yam ) made with fried sun-dried salted fish ( pla khem ).

yam-pla-salit.notes: A Thai salad made with deep-fried, sun-dried snakeskin gourami..

yam-pla-thu.notes: Made with short mackerel ( pla thu ).

yam-sanat.notes: A northern Thai salad of roughly chopped, blanched vegetables that are then refried with a chili paste. It is served here together with northern Thai pork cracklings and deep-fried, sun-dried chili peppers.

yam-som-o.notes: A salad made with pomelo. The other ingredients are: sliced red bird's eye chili peppers, deep-fried sun-dried anchovies, roasted peanuts, fish sauce and tamarind juice.

yam-takhrai-kung-sot.notes: A spicy "yam-style" salad with finely sliced raw lemongrass and prawns.
yam-takhrai-kung-sot.thai: ยำตะไคร้กุ้งสด

yam-thale.notes: A spicy salad with mixed seafood (cuttlefish, shelled prawns, mussels), shallots, lime juice, fish sauce and Thai celery.

yam-thua-phu.notes: A Thai salad with winged beans, salted eggs, toasted coconut, shallots, fish sauce, lime juice and chilis. The version in this image also contains squid.

yam-wun-sen.notes: A spicy salad with glass noodles ( cellophane noodles ), minced chicken or pork and often either mixed seafood, squid or prawns. Cloud ear fungus also often features in this dish.
yam-wun-sen.thai: ยำวุ้นเส้น

yang-ruam-mu.notes: A northern Thai dish of different cuts of pork (including pig udder) that have been grilled. It is served with a dipping sauce.
yang-ruam-mu.thai: ย่างรวมหมู

yentafo.notes: The Thai version of the Chinese noodle dish Yong Tau Foo is slightly sweet, sour, salty, and spicy.

yum-kanom-jeen.notes: Yum kanomjeen is a spicy and sour salad mixed with kanom jeen. Kanom jeen is thin rice noodles which are made from fresh rice sometimes fermented rice starch, fermented for few days, boiled and then made into noodles. The original kanom jeen came from the Mon people. The main ingredients of Yum kanom jeen are fish sauce, sugar, lime juice, and chili powder. Some places will add pla ra to Yum kanom jeen too. Pla ra is the Thai traditional ingredient produced by fermented fish. Yum kanom jeen has a good spicy and sour taste, but many people would like to order the flavor that they like. Yum kanom jeen is a low- calorie food and it has only 220 calories per dish. To suit for people who are healthy and want to diet. Yum kanom jeen is not difficult to find. It can be found in either restaurant or street food.

077 Gari Bap Sai Gai.chatgpt: Curry-Puffs sind kleine, knusprige Teigtaschen, die mit einer würzigen Füllung aus Hähnchen, Kartoffeln, Zwiebeln und Curry-Gewürzen gefüllt sind. Sie stammen ursprünglich aus der malaiischen und indischen Küche, sind aber auch in Thailand sehr beliebt. Der Teig ist butterig und blättrig, ähnlich wie ein Blätterteig oder ein Pie-Teig. Die Puffs werden meist frittiert oder gebacken und als Snack oder Streetfood verkauft.
